descriptions.breath-awareness: Gently attend to the natural breath. When attention wanders, return without judgment.
descriptions.loving-kindness: Cultivate warm goodwill for yourself and others using short phrases.
descriptions.focus-candle: Rest attention on the flame’s shape, light and shadow as a single visual anchor.
descriptions.body-scan-5m: Sweep attention through the body from toes to head, noticing sensations as they are.
descriptions.open-monitoring: Open awareness to any experience—sounds, thoughts, sensations—without choosing a single anchor.
descriptions.noting: When you notice a distraction, softly label it (e.g., “thinking”, “hearing”) and return.
descriptions.pmr-6m: Gently tense and release major muscle groups to downshift arousal and invite sleep.
descriptions.safe-place-imagery: Imagine a vividly safe, soothing place to reduce anxiety and promote calm.

breath-awareness.why: Mindful breathing increases attentional control and reduces amygdala reactivity; clinical trials link it to lower perceived stress and improved HRV.
steps: Sit comfortably; lengthen spine; relax jaw and shoulders.
Notice the breath at one spot (nostrils or belly).
When the mind wanders, gently note it and return to the breath.
Continue at a natural pace.
breath-awareness.tip: Choose a single breath location; keep the return gentle.

loving-kindness.why: Compassion practices increase positive affect and social connectedness; meta-analyses show reductions in self-criticism and depressive symptoms.
steps: Bring to mind yourself or someone easy to care for.
Silently repeat phrases like: “May you be safe. May you be healthy. May you be peaceful.”
Let the tone be warm and sincere; if difficult, start neutral (e.g., a pet or benefactor).
Expand to others as time allows.
loving-kindness.tip: Adjust phrases to feel natural in your own words.

focus-candle.why: Single-pointed attention reduces mind-wandering and trains sustained focus; visual anchors can rapidly stabilize attention networks.
steps: Place a lit candle at eye level, ~1–2 meters away.
Soften the gaze on the flame’s shape, color and halo.
When pulled away, note “thinking/seeing” and return.
Keep blinks natural; shoulders relaxed.
focus-candle.tip: If eyes tire, close briefly and visualize the flame.

body-scan-5m.why: Interoceptive training reduces rumination and improves pain and stress tolerance by recruiting somatosensory networks.
steps: Lie down or sit; soften gaze or close eyes.
Start at toes; notice contact, temperature, tingling or neutral.
Progress slowly: feet → calves → knees → thighs → hips → belly → chest → shoulders → arms/hands → neck → face → scalp.
If distracted, return to the last body area.
body-scan-5m.tip: Notice without trying to change sensations.

open-monitoring.why: Open monitoring increases nonreactivity and cognitive flexibility; studies show reduced stress and improved attentional breadth.
steps: Sit upright; breathe naturally.
Allow sounds, sensations, thoughts to arise and pass.
Notice beginnings and endings without pursuing any one object.
If you get hooked, acknowledge “caught” and re-open.
open-monitoring.tip: Think of awareness as a spacious room; experiences move through.

noting.why: Labeling (“affect labeling”) reduces limbic activation and improves attentional switching; helpful for rumination.
whyBullets: Supports quick returns to the task
steps: Choose a gentle anchor (breath or sounds).
When a distraction appears, softly label it: “thinking”, “planning”, “hearing”, “feeling”.
Return to the anchor without judgment.
Repeat as many times as needed.
noting.tip: Keep labels short and quiet—just enough to notice.

pmr-6m.why: Progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) reduces sympathetic arousal and improves sleep onset by alternating tension and release.
steps: While seated or lying down, inhale and gently tense feet and calves for ~3–5s.
Exhale and fully release. Move to thighs and hips.
Continue through belly/chest, hands/arms, shoulders, face/jaw.
Finish with one slow, deep breath and full body release.
pmr-6m.tip: Keep tension gentle—aim for awareness, not strain.

safe-place-imagery.why: Guided imagery activates parasympathetic pathways and can reduce anxiety; trauma-informed protocols often include a safe-place exercise.
steps: Close eyes and picture a place that feels safe and soothing (real or imagined).
Engage senses: colors, sounds, temperature, scents, textures.
Add a supportive phrase (e.g., “Here I am safe.”).
Rest there for several breaths; return when ready.
safe-place-imagery.tip: If visualizing is hard, build it slowly using one sense at a time.
